awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Media Exposure, Objective Knowledge, Risk Perceptions, and Risk Management Preferences of Americans Regarding the Novel Coronavirus Outbreak
awd_abstract_narration:
The sudden observation in Wuhan, China, in December, 2019, of humans infected with a new virus (officially 2019-nCoV virus and COVID-19 disease, publicly known as “the coronavirus”) provides yet another example of scientists and policymakers being surprised as a virus observed in animal and/or bird populations, or transmitted by mosquitoes, became infectious and damaging in humans (e.g., two coronaviruses: SARS 2002-2003, MERS 2012; recent major outbreaks of Ebola virus, 2014-2016, and Zika virus, 2015-2017). Understanding dynamics of public responses to such events under uncertainty is necessary to learn how to avoid either undue apathy or undue panic. This project explores how Americans’ views of and behavior towards the coronavirus change—or do not change—over 9 months. This will serve the national interest in progress in science by improving our understanding of how people’s beliefs, attitudes, and behaviors interact both within the same person over time, and between people with individual differences in attitudes at a given time. The research tests a novel model of how views of personal and collective solutions to what appears to be an emerging pandemic are affected by beliefs and attitudes, which builds upon prior work including the Protection Action Decision Model. The research also may improve public health and prosperity by revealing what factors are associated with particular reactions that may make public health protection easier or harder to implement. It thus affects whether quarantines, travel bans, and other policies meant to be protective hamper or amplify economic growth as well. The project also tests messages about false beliefs and flu vaccine efficacy that may inform public health risk communication and thus improve public health.


A longitudinal study design surveys the same Americans five times at 2-month intervals, thus over 9 months total. Each wave of the project asks the same questions: perceived risk; emotional reactions to the virus; reported personal protective behavior and support for actual or potential government policies; and beliefs about those behaviors and policies; trust in government; subjective and objective knowledge about the virus; psychological distance from the virus; how much individuals are following news about the virus; and which types of traditional and social media sources they use and which outlets they use (e.g., different TV channels or different social media sites). Repeating these questions over time allows the research team to examine whether changes occur in these views and behaviors over time, or relations between factors over time (for example, do risk perceptions actually predict later protective behaviors). Certain other factors, such as culture, conspiracy thoughts, and blatant and subtle prejudice—are measured during one survey wave as a control. The survey is complemented by content analysis of mass and social media information from sources that respondents report using, so the researchers can test effects of that exposure on objective knowledge, risk perceptions, and behaviors. An information manipulation experiment embedded in the last survey will allow testing of whether vaccination intentions for the influenza (“flu”) virus can be increased in light of perceived threat from this coronavirus, and whether false beliefs about the coronavirus threat and management can be diminished in the short-term.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project studied how Americans react to hazards, surveying the same people about the COVID-19 pandemic six times from February 2020 (then under 50 confirmed U.S. cases) through April 2021 (public vaccination ongoing for a few months). This most severe infectious disease threat since the 1918 influenza pandemic offered an unprecedented opportunity to grasp how people respond to an unforeseen disease threat.

            Early (February 2020) responses were lower, with more disagreement, than in later waves, after formal emergency declarations. Risk perceptions were shaped by how immediate the threat seemed and how likely to affect people like oneself (temporal and social proximity), and with following pandemic news. While risk perceptions and perceived attributes of protective actions (for example, response efficacy [belief a behavior would reduce risk] and self-efficacy [belief it was something the person could implement]) increased intentions to adopt protective actions, trust in authorities and belief that the pandemic was temporally and socially distant reduced intentions.

            Trends in risk perceptions 2020-2021 varied by whether individuals believed in temporal distance and their own knowledge about viral transmission, and whether local infections were increasing their upward trend (from official data). We asked about risk perceptions for self and one’s family (personal), collective (U.S.; global), affective (concern, dread, bad feelings), severity (expected number of U.S. COVID-19 cases and deaths by pandemic end), and duration (how long they expected the pandemic to last). Not only did trends vary across risk perception measures, but contradicting social science expectations, personal risk perceptions were not the strongest predictors of protective behaviors, far outweighed by collective risk perceptions, followed by affective perceptions (same for supporting protective policies). The study also found problems with risk perception measurement. For example, bad feelings had a different pattern than dread and concern, despite all three deemed affective, and duration a different pattern than expected cases/deaths, despite all three deemed severity measures. In another example, the study used two personal risk perception items: one item conditional on non-action (“if you or your family doesn’t do anything new to protect yourself”), the other conditional on action (“do anything new”). It is typical for researchers to ask about personal risk without mentioning behavior, which means that in answering, people can take into account their recent intention or anticipated behavior, obscuring true risk perception-behavior relationships. Here the non-action risk perception measure indicated more risk, as expected, and it was more stable over time. Using the conditional no-action personal risk perception item, we tested hypotheses about its relationship to behavior rarely tested properly (most require measuring responses over time, while most studies examine the relationship at one time point). We examined six behaviors: hand washing, mask wearing, avoiding travel to infected areas, avoiding large public gatherings, vaccination, and (for waves 2-6) social isolation at home. Behavioral motivation—people with high risk perception now adopt more protective behavior later—was strongly supported, while risk reappraisal—taking protective behavior now lowers risk perceptions later—was strongly refuted, perhaps reflecting continuing uncertainty about efficacy of COVID-19 protective behaviors and/or that dynamic infectious diseases may yield different patterns than the chronic diseases for which these hypotheses have mostly been tested before.

            Another focus was the role of culture—specifically, whether people support a hierarchical way of life valuing order, an individualist way of life (liberty), an egalitarian way of life (equality), or a fatalist way of life (good luck). First, we compared Wave 2 of this study (April/May 2020) with a parallel Chinese study (May-June 2020). Culture had mostly indirect effects on behavior: in both countries, more hierarchist views increased beliefs about response efficacy and self-efficacy, which then increased all protective behaviors, while this pattern varied across the two nations for other cultural biases and by behaviors. Trust in government was only a significant China mediator (that is, a link between cultural biases and behavior), while risk perception was only a significant U.S. mediator. In a separate U.S.-only analysis, culture’s effect on risk perceptions, behavior and policy support was examined for two affective mediators—hazard affect (dread) and solution aversion (perceived threat to one’s values from a specific behavior or policy). These affective mediators were suggested separately—hazard affect deemed to increase risk responses, solution aversion deemed to decrease them—but rarely tested at all, much less against each other. Here solution aversion was the stronger factor for risk perceptions, behavior and policy support, with only rare direct effects (mainly for egalitarians, who saw greater threat, adopted more protective behavior, and supported protective policies more), and indirect effects for egalitarians, political conservatives, and individualists (the latter two with lower risk responses).

            Overall, this study expanded scientific understanding of how risk responses shift over time, how to measure these responses, and their inter-relationships (e.g., with behavior), thus helping to improve future responses to pandemics and other threats to public safety.
